 # == Configuration
 #
 # Like railties, engines can access a config object which contains configuration shared by
 # all railties and the application.
 # Additionally, each engine can access <tt>autoload_paths</tt>, <tt>eager_load_paths</tt> and
 # <tt>autoload_once_paths</tt> settings which are scoped to that engine.
 #
 # class MyEngine < Rails::Engine
 # # Add a load path for this specific Engine
 # config.autoload_paths << File.expand_path("lib/some/path", __dir__)
 #
 # initializer "my_engine.add_middleware" do |app|
 # app.middleware.use MyEngine::Middleware
 # end
 # end
 #
 # == Generators
 #
 # You can set up generators for engines with <tt>config.generators</tt> method:
 #
 # class MyEngine < Rails::Engine
 # config.generators do |g|
 # g.orm :active_record
 # g.template_engine :erb
 # g.test_framework :test_unit
 # end
 # end
 #
 # You can also set generators for an application by using <tt>config.app_generators</tt>:
 #
 # class MyEngine < Rails::Engine
 # # note that you can also pass block to app_generators in the same way you
 # # can pass it to generators method
 # config.app_generators.orm :datamapper
 # end
 #
 # == Paths
 #
 # Applications and engines have flexible path configuration, meaning that you
 # are not required to place your controllers at <tt>app/controllers</tt>, but
 # in any place which you find convenient.
 #
 # For example, let's suppose you want to place your controllers in <tt>lib/controllers</tt>.
 # You can set that as an option:
 #
 # class MyEngine < Rails::Engine
 # paths["app/controllers"] = "lib/controllers"
 # end
 #
 # You can also have your controllers loaded from both <tt>app/controllers</tt> and
 # <tt>lib/controllers</tt>:
 #
 # class MyEngine < Rails::Engine
 # paths["app/controllers"] << "lib/controllers"
 # end
 #
 # The available paths in an engine are:
 #
 # class MyEngine < Rails::Engine
 # paths["app"] # => ["app"]
 # paths["app/controllers"] # => ["app/controllers"]
 # paths["app/helpers"] # => ["app/helpers"]
 # paths["app/models"] # => ["app/models"]
 # paths["app/views"] # => ["app/views"]
 # paths["lib"] # => ["lib"]
 # paths["lib/tasks"] # => ["lib/tasks"]
 # paths["config"] # => ["config"]
 # paths["config/initializers"] # => ["config/initializers"]
 # paths["config/locales"] # => ["config/locales"]
 # paths["config/routes.rb"] # => ["config/routes.rb"]
 # end
 #
 # The <tt>Application</tt> class adds a couple more paths to this set. And as in your
 # <tt>Application</tt>, all folders under +app+ are automatically added to the load path.
 # If you have an <tt>app/services</tt> folder for example, it will be added by default.
 #
 # == Endpoint
 #
 # An engine can also be a Rack application. It can be useful if you have a Rack application that
 # you would like to provide with some of the +Engine+'s features.
 #
 # To do that, use the ::endpoint method:
 #
 # module MyEngine
 # class Engine < Rails::Engine
 # endpoint MyRackApplication
 # end
 # end
 #
 # Now you can mount your engine in application's routes:
 #
 # Rails.application.routes.draw do
 # mount MyEngine::Engine => "/engine"
 # end
 #
 # == Middleware stack
 #
 # As an engine can now be a Rack endpoint, it can also have a middleware
 # stack. The usage is exactly the same as in <tt>Application</tt>:
 #
 # module MyEngine
 # class Engine < Rails::Engine
 # middleware.use SomeMiddleware
 # end
 # end
 #
 # == Routes
 #
 # If you don't specify an endpoint, routes will be used as the default
 # endpoint. You can use them just like you use an application's routes:
 #
 # # ENGINE/config/routes.rb
 # MyEngine::Engine.routes.draw do
 # get "/" => "posts#index"
 # end
 #
 # == Mount priority
 #
 # Note that now there can be more than one router in your application, and it's better to avoid
 # passing requests through many routers. Consider this situation:
 #
 # Rails.application.routes.draw do
 # mount MyEngine::Engine => "/blog"
 # get "/blog/omg" => "main#omg"
 # end
 #
 # +MyEngine+ is mounted at <tt>/blog</tt>, and <tt>/blog/omg</tt> points to application's
 # controller. In such a situation, requests to <tt>/blog/omg</tt> will go through +MyEngine+,
 # and if there is no such route in +Engine+'s routes, it will be dispatched to <tt>main#omg</tt>.
 # It's much better to swap that:
 #
 # Rails.application.routes.draw do
 # get "/blog/omg" => "main#omg"
 # mount MyEngine::Engine => "/blog"
 # end
 #
 # Now, +Engine+ will get only requests that were not handled by +Application+.
 #
 # == Engine name
 #
 # There are some places where an Engine's name is used:
 #
 # * routes: when you mount an Engine with <tt>mount(MyEngine::Engine => '/my_engine')</tt>,
 # it's used as default <tt>:as</tt> option
 # * rake task for installing migrations <tt>my_engine:install:migrations</tt>
 #
 # Engine name is set by default based on class name. For +MyEngine::Engine+ it will be
 # <tt>my_engine_engine</tt>. You can change it manually using the <tt>engine_name</tt> method:
 #
 # module MyEngine
 # class Engine < Rails::Engine
 # engine_name "my_engine"
 # end
 # end
 #
 # == Isolated Engine
 #
 # Normally when you create controllers, helpers, and models inside an engine, they are treated
 # as if they were created inside the application itself. This means that all helpers and
 # named routes from the application will be available to your engine's controllers as well.
 #
 # However, sometimes you want to isolate your engine from the application, especially if your engine
 # has its own router. To do that, you simply need to call ::isolate_namespace. This method requires
 # you to pass a module where all your controllers, helpers, and models should be nested to:
 #
 # module MyEngine
 # class Engine < Rails::Engine
 # isolate_namespace MyEngine
 # end
 # end
 #
 # With such an engine, everything that is inside the +MyEngine+ module will be isolated from
 # the application.
 #
 # Consider this controller:
 #
 # module MyEngine
 # class FooController < ActionController::Base
 # end
 # end
 #
 # If the +MyEngine+ engine is marked as isolated, +FooController+ only has
 # access to helpers from +MyEngine+, and <tt>url_helpers</tt> from
 # <tt>MyEngine::Engine.routes</tt>.
 #
 # The next thing that changes in isolated engines is the behavior of routes.
 # Normally, when you namespace your controllers, you also need to namespace
 # the related routes. With an isolated engine, the engine's namespace is
 # automatically applied, so you don't need to specify it explicitly in your
 # routes:
 #
 # MyEngine::Engine.routes.draw do
 # resources :articles
 # end
 #
 # If +MyEngine+ is isolated, the routes above will point to
 # +MyEngine::ArticlesController+. You also don't need to use longer
 # URL helpers like +my_engine_articles_path+. Instead, you should simply use
 # +articles_path+, like you would do with your main application.
 #
 # To make this behavior consistent with other parts of the framework,
 # isolated engines also have an effect on ActiveModel::Naming. In a
 # normal \Rails app, when you use a namespaced model such as
 # +Namespace::Article+, ActiveModel::Naming will generate
 # names with the prefix "namespace". In an isolated engine, the prefix will
 # be omitted in URL helpers and form fields, for convenience.
 #
 # polymorphic_url(MyEngine::Article.new)
 # # => "articles_path" # not "my_engine_articles_path"
 #
 # form_with(model: MyEngine::Article.new) do
 # text_field :title # => <input type="text" name="article[title]" id="article_title" />
 # end
 #
 # Additionally, an isolated engine will set its own name according to its
 # namespace, so <tt>MyEngine::Engine.engine_name</tt> will return
 # "my_engine". It will also set +MyEngine.table_name_prefix+ to "my_engine_",
 # meaning for example that +MyEngine::Article+ will use the
 # +my_engine_articles+ database table by default.
 #
 # == Using Engine's routes outside Engine
 #
 # Since you can now mount an engine inside application's routes, you do not have direct access to +Engine+'s
 # <tt>url_helpers</tt> inside +Application+. When you mount an engine in an application's routes, a special helper is
 # created to allow you to do that. Consider such a scenario:
 #
 # # config/routes.rb
 # Rails.application.routes.draw do
 # mount MyEngine::Engine => "/my_engine", as: "my_engine"
 # get "/foo" => "foo#index"
 # end
 #
 # Now, you can use the <tt>my_engine</tt> helper inside your application:
 #
 # class FooController < ApplicationController
 # def index
 # my_engine.root_url # => /my_engine/
 # end
 # end
 #
 # There is also a <tt>main_app</tt> helper that gives you access to application's routes inside Engine:
 #
 # module MyEngine
 # class BarController
 # def index
 # main_app.foo_path # => /foo
 # end
 # end
 # end
 #
 # Note that the <tt>:as</tt> option given to mount takes the <tt>engine_name</tt> as default, so most of the time
 # you can simply omit it.
 #
 # Finally, if you want to generate a URL to an engine's route using
 # <tt>polymorphic_url</tt>, you also need to pass the engine helper. Let's
 # say that you want to create a form pointing to one of the engine's routes.
 # All you need to do is pass the helper as the first element in array with
 # attributes for URL:
 #
 # form_with(model: [my_engine, @user])
 #
 # This code will use <tt>my_engine.user_path(@user)</tt> to generate the proper route.
 #
 # == Isolated engine's helpers
 #
 # Sometimes you may want to isolate an engine, but use helpers that are defined for it.
 # If you want to share just a few specific helpers you can add them to application's
 # helpers in ApplicationController:
 #
 # class ApplicationController < ActionController::Base
 # helper MyEngine::SharedEngineHelper
 # end
 #
 # If you want to include all of the engine's helpers, you can use the #helper method on an engine's
 # instance:
 #
 # class ApplicationController < ActionController::Base
 # helper MyEngine::Engine.helpers
 # end
 #
 # It will include all of the helpers from engine's directory. Take into account this does
 # not include helpers defined in controllers with helper_method or other similar solutions,
 # only helpers defined in the helpers directory will be included.
 #
 # == Migrations & seed data
 #
 # Engines can have their own migrations. The default path for migrations is exactly the same
 # as in application: <tt>db/migrate</tt>
 #
 # To use engine's migrations in application you can use the rake task below, which copies them to
 # application's dir:
 #
 # $ rake ENGINE_NAME:install:migrations
 #
 # Note that some of the migrations may be skipped if a migration with the same name already exists
 # in application. In such a situation you must decide whether to leave that migration or rename the
 # migration in the application and rerun copying migrations.
 #
 # If your engine has migrations, you may also want to prepare data for the database in
 # the <tt>db/seeds.rb</tt> file. You can load that data using the <tt>load_seed</tt> method, e.g.
 #
 # MyEngine::Engine.load_seed
 #
 # == Loading priority
 #
 # In order to change engine's priority you can use +config.railties_order+ in the main application.
 # It will affect the priority of loading views, helpers, assets, and all the other files
 # related to engine or application.
 #
 # # load Blog::Engine with highest priority, followed by application and other railties
 # config.railties_order = [Blog::Engine, :main_app, :all]
 class Engine < Railtie
 autoload :Configuration, "rails/engine/configuration"
 autoload :LazyRouteSet, "rails/engine/lazy_route_set"

 class << self
 attr_accessor :called_from, :isolated

 alias :isolated? :isolated
 alias :engine_name :railtie_name

 delegate :eager_load!, to: :instance

 def inherited(base)
 unless base.abstract_railtie?
 Rails::Railtie::Configuration.eager_load_namespaces << base

 base.called_from = begin
 call_stack = caller_locations.map { |l| l.absolute_path || l.path }

 File.dirname(call_stack.detect { |p| !p.match?(%r[railties[\w.-]*/lib/rails|rack[\w.-]*/lib/rack]) })
 end
 end

 super
 end

 def find_root(from)
 find_root_with_flag "lib", from
 end

 def endpoint(endpoint = nil)
 @endpoint ||= nil
 @endpoint = endpoint if endpoint
 @endpoint
 end

 def isolate_namespace(mod)
 engine_name(generate_railtie_name(mod.name))

 config.default_scope = { module: ActiveSupport::Inflector.underscore(mod.name) }

 self.isolated = true

 unless mod.respond_to?(:railtie_namespace)
 name, railtie = engine_name, self

 mod.singleton_class.instance_eval do
 define_method(:railtie_namespace) { railtie }

 unless mod.respond_to?(:table_name_prefix)
 define_method(:table_name_prefix) { "#{name}_" }

 ActiveSupport.on_load(:active_record) do
 mod.singleton_class.redefine_method(:table_name_prefix) do
 "#{ActiveRecord::Base.table_name_prefix}#{name}_"
 end
 end
 end

 unless mod.respond_to?(:use_relative_model_naming?)
 class_eval "def use_relative_model_naming?; true; end", __FILE__, __LINE__
 end

 unless mod.respond_to?(:railtie_helpers_paths)
 define_method(:railtie_helpers_paths) { railtie.helpers_paths }
 end

 unless mod.respond_to?(:railtie_routes_url_helpers)
 define_method(:railtie_routes_url_helpers) { |include_path_helpers = true| railtie.routes.url_helpers(include_path_helpers) }
 end
 end
 end
 end

 # Finds engine with given path.
 def find(path)
 expanded_path = File.expand_path path
 Rails::Engine.subclasses.each do |klass|
 engine = klass.instance
 return engine if File.expand_path(engine.root) == expanded_path
 end
 nil
 end
 end

 include ActiveSupport::Callbacks
 define_callbacks :load_seed

 delegate :middleware, :root, :paths, to: :config
 delegate :engine_name, :isolated?, to: :class

 def initialize
 @_all_autoload_paths = nil
 @_all_load_paths = nil
 @app = nil
 @config = nil
 @env_config = nil
 @helpers = nil
 @routes = nil
 @app_build_lock = Mutex.new
 super
 end

 # Load console and invoke the registered hooks.
 # Check Rails::Railtie.console for more info.
 def load_console(app = self)
 run_console_blocks(app)
 self
 end

 # Load \Rails runner and invoke the registered hooks.
 # Check Rails::Railtie.runner for more info.
 def load_runner(app = self)
 run_runner_blocks(app)
 self
 end

 # Load Rake and railties tasks, and invoke the registered hooks.
 # Check Rails::Railtie.rake_tasks for more info.
 def load_tasks(app = self)
 require "rake"
 run_tasks_blocks(app)
 self
 end

 # Load \Rails generators and invoke the registered hooks.
 # Check Rails::Railtie.generators for more info.
 def load_generators(app = self)
 require "rails/generators"
 run_generators_blocks(app)
 Rails::Generators.configure!(app.config.generators)
 self
 end

 # Invoke the server registered hooks.
 # Check Rails::Railtie.server for more info.
 def load_server(app = self)
 run_server_blocks(app)
 self
 end

 def eager_load!
 # Already done by Zeitwerk::Loader.eager_load_all. By now, we leave the
 # method as a no-op for backwards compatibility.
 end

 def railties
 @railties ||= Railties.new
 end

 # Returns a module with all the helpers defined for the engine.
 def helpers
 @helpers ||= begin
 helpers = Module.new
 AbstractController::Helpers.helper_modules_from_paths(helpers_paths).each do |mod|
 helpers.include(mod)
 end
 helpers
 end
 end

 # Returns all registered helpers paths.
 def helpers_paths
 paths["app/helpers"].existent
 end

 # Returns the underlying Rack application for this engine.
 def app
 @app || @app_build_lock.synchronize {
 @app ||= begin
 stack = default_middleware_stack
 config.middleware = build_middleware.merge_into(stack)
 config.middleware.build(endpoint)
 end
 }
 end

 # Returns the endpoint for this engine. If none is registered,
 # defaults to an ActionDispatch::Routing::RouteSet.
 def endpoint
 self.class.endpoint || routes
 end

 # Define the Rack API for this engine.
 def call(env)
 req = build_request env
 app.call req.env
 end

 # Defines additional Rack env configuration that is added on each call.
 def env_config
 @env_config ||= {}
 end

 # Defines the routes for this engine. If a block is given to
 # routes, it is appended to the engine.
 def routes(&block)
 @routes ||= config.route_set_class.new_with_config(config)
 @routes.append(&block) if block_given?
 @routes
 end

 # Define the configuration object for the engine.
 def config
 @config ||= Engine::Configuration.new(self.class.find_root(self.class.called_from))
 end

 # Load data from db/seeds.rb file. It can be used in to load engines'
 # seeds, e.g.:
 #
 # Blog::Engine.load_seed
 def load_seed
 seed_file = paths["db/seeds.rb"].existent.first
 run_callbacks(:load_seed) { load(seed_file) } if seed_file
 end

 initializer :load_environment_config, before: :load_environment_hook, group: :all do
 paths["config/environments"].existent.each do |environment|
 require environment
 end
 end

 initializer :set_load_path, before: :bootstrap_hook do |app|
 _all_load_paths(app.config.add_autoload_paths_to_load_path).reverse_each do |path|
 $LOAD_PATH.unshift(path) if File.directory?(path)
 end
 $LOAD_PATH.uniq!
 end

 initializer :set_autoload_paths, before: :bootstrap_hook do
 ActiveSupport::Dependencies.autoload_paths.unshift(*_all_autoload_paths)
 ActiveSupport::Dependencies.autoload_once_paths.unshift(*_all_autoload_once_paths)

 config.autoload_paths.freeze
 config.autoload_once_paths.freeze
 end

 initializer :set_eager_load_paths, before: :bootstrap_hook do
 ActiveSupport::Dependencies._eager_load_paths.merge(config.all_eager_load_paths)
 config.eager_load_paths.freeze
 end

 initializer :make_routes_lazy, before: :bootstrap_hook do |app|
 config.route_set_class = LazyRouteSet if Rails.env.local?
 end

 initializer :add_routing_paths do |app|
 routing_paths = paths["config/routes.rb"].existent
 external_paths = self.paths["config/routes"].paths
 routes.draw_paths.concat(external_paths)
 app.routes.draw_paths.concat(external_paths)

 if routes? || routing_paths.any?
 app.routes_reloader.paths.unshift(*routing_paths)
 app.routes_reloader.route_sets << routes
 app.routes_reloader.external_routes.unshift(*external_paths)
 end
 end

 # I18n load paths are a special case since the ones added
 # later have higher priority.
 initializer :add_locales do
 config.i18n.railties_load_path << paths["config/locales"]
 end

 initializer :add_view_paths do
 views = paths["app/views"].existent
 unless views.empty?
 ActiveSupport.on_load(:action_controller) { prepend_view_path(views) if respond_to?(:prepend_view_path) }
 ActiveSupport.on_load(:action_mailer) { prepend_view_path(views) }
 end
 end

 initializer :add_mailer_preview_paths do
 previews = paths["test/mailers/previews"].existent
 unless previews.empty?
 ActiveSupport.on_load(:action_mailer) { self.preview_paths |= previews }
 end
 end

 initializer :add_fixture_paths do
 next if is_a?(Rails::Application)

 fixtures = config.root.join("test", "fixtures")
 if fixtures_in_root_and_not_in_vendor_or_dot_dir?(fixtures)
 ActiveSupport.on_load(:active_record_fixtures) { self.fixture_paths |= ["#{fixtures}/"] }
 end
 end

 initializer :prepend_helpers_path do |app|
 if !isolated? || (app == self)
 app.config.helpers_paths.unshift(*paths["app/helpers"].existent)
 end
 end

 initializer :load_config_initializers do
 config.paths["config/initializers"].existent.sort.each do |initializer|
 load_config_initializer(initializer)
 end
 end

 initializer :wrap_reloader_around_load_seed do |app|
 self.class.set_callback(:load_seed, :around) do |engine, seeds_block|
 app.reloader.wrap(&seeds_block)
 end
 end

 initializer :engines_blank_point do
 # We need this initializer so all extra initializers added in engines are
 # consistently executed after all the initializers above across all engines.
 end

 rake_tasks do
 next if is_a?(Rails::Application)
 next unless has_migrations?

 namespace railtie_name do
 namespace :install do
 desc "Copy migrations from #{railtie_name} to application"
 task :migrations do
 ENV["FROM"] = railtie_name
 if Rake::Task.task_defined?("railties:install:migrations")
 Rake::Task["railties:install:migrations"].invoke
 else
 Rake::Task["app:railties:install:migrations"].invoke
 end
 end
 end
 end
 end

 def routes? # :nodoc:
 @routes
 end

 protected
 def run_tasks_blocks(*) # :nodoc:
 super
 paths["lib/tasks"].existent.sort.each { |ext| load(ext) }
 end

 private
 def load_config_initializer(initializer) # :doc:
 ActiveSupport::Notifications.instrument("load_config_initializer.railties", initializer: initializer) do
 load(initializer)
 end
 end

 def has_migrations?
 paths["db/migrate"].existent.any?
 end

 def self.find_root_with_flag(flag, root_path, default = nil) # :nodoc:
 while root_path && File.directory?(root_path) && !File.exist?("#{root_path}/#{flag}")
 parent = File.dirname(root_path)
 root_path = parent != root_path && parent
 end

 root = File.exist?("#{root_path}/#{flag}") ? root_path : default
 raise "Could not find root path for #{self}" unless root

 Pathname.new File.realpath root
 end

 def default_middleware_stack
 ActionDispatch::MiddlewareStack.new
 end

 def _all_autoload_once_paths
 config.all_autoload_once_paths.uniq
 end

 def _all_autoload_paths
 @_all_autoload_paths ||= begin
 autoload_paths = config.all_autoload_paths
 autoload_paths += config.all_eager_load_paths
 autoload_paths -= config.all_autoload_once_paths
 autoload_paths.uniq
 end
 end

 def _all_load_paths(add_autoload_paths_to_load_path)
 @_all_load_paths ||= begin
 load_paths = config.paths.load_paths
 if add_autoload_paths_to_load_path
 load_paths += _all_autoload_paths
 load_paths += _all_autoload_once_paths
 end
 load_paths.uniq
 end
 end

 def fixtures_in_root_and_not_in_vendor_or_dot_dir?(fixtures)
 fixtures.exist? && fixtures.to_s.start_with?(Rails.root.to_s) &&
 !fixtures.to_s.start_with?(Rails.root.join("vendor").to_s) &&
 !fixtures.to_s.start_with?("#{Rails.root}/.".to_s)
 end

 def build_request(env)
 env.merge!(env_config)
 req = ActionDispatch::Request.new env
 req.routes = routes
 req.engine_script_name = req.script_name
 req
 end

 def build_middleware
 config.middleware
 end
 end
end

I've implemented a comprehensive solution to address both issues:

1. **Preventing 304 Not Modified Responses**:
 - Added cache control headers to prevent caching (`no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate`)
 - Added an `after_action` to explicitly remove ETag and Last-Modified headers
 - Overridden the `fresh_when` method to prevent conditional responses

2. **Ensuring JSON Content Type**:
 - Added a `set_default_format` method that sets both the request format and response content type to JSON
 - Kept the route configuration with `defaults: { format: :json }`

These changes should ensure that:
1. Your API always returns a 200 OK response with the full JSON payload, never a 304 Not Modified
2. The response content type is always `application/json`

## How to Test

To verify these changes are working:

1. **For 304 Responses**:
 ```bash
 # First request
 curl -i http://localhost:3000/api/v1/catalog/beads
 
 # Second request with the ETag from the first response
 curl -i -H "If-None-Match: \"the-etag-value\"" http://localhost:3000/api/v1/catalog/beads
 ```
 You should get a 200 response with full JSON content for both requests.

2. **For Content Type**:
 ```bash
 curl -i http://localhost:3000/api/v1/catalog/beads
 ```
 Check that the response headers include `Content-Type: application/json`.

## Additional Notes

1. **Performance Consideration**: Disabling caching means every request will generate a full response, which might increase server load. This is a trade-off between consistent behavior and performance.

2. **Browser Behavior**: Browsers might still cache responses based on their own heuristics, but they should respect the cache control headers we've set.

3. **API Documentation**: Consider documenting that your API doesn't support caching via ETags or Last-Modified headers, so clients don't attempt to use conditional requests.

 end

I've implemented several layers of fixes to ensure your API always returns responses with the `application/json` content type:

1. **Controller-Level Fixes**:
 - Added `set_default_format` method to `ApiController` to set both request format and response content type
 - Added `ensure_json_response` after_action to `BaseController` to ensure content type is set correctly

2. **Middleware Fixes**:
 - Created a custom middleware (`ApiContentTypeMiddleware`) that:
 - Sets the `Accept` header to `application/json` for all API requests
 - Forces the `Content-Type` header to `application/json; charset=utf-8` for all API responses
 - Placed this middleware at the beginning of the stack to ensure it runs first

3. **Renderer Configuration**:
 - Added a custom JSON renderer that explicitly sets the content type to `application/json`

4. **Route Configuration**:
 - Kept the `defaults: { format: :json }` in the routes configuration

These changes provide multiple layers of protection to ensure your API always returns responses with the correct content type. If one layer fails, the others should still work.

## How to Test

To verify these changes are working:

```bash
curl -i http://localhost:3000/api/v1/catalog/beads
```

Check that the response headers include `Content-Type: application/json` or `Content-Type: application/json; charset=utf-8`.

You can also test in your browser by navigating to an API endpoint and checking the Network tab in the developer tools to see the content type of the response.

## Additional Notes

1. **Restart Required**: You'll need to restart your Rails server for these changes to take effect, especially the middleware and initializer changes.

2. **Debugging**: If you're still seeing issues, you can add debugging to the middleware to see what's happening:
 ```ruby
 puts "Request path: #{env['PATH_INFO']}"
 puts "Accept header: #{env['HTTP_ACCEPT']}"
 puts "Content-Type: #{headers['Content-Type']}"
 ```

3. **Browser Behavior**: Some browsers might still display the response as HTML if they think they can render it, but the actual content type should be `application/json`.

I've implemented multiple layers of fixes to ensure your API always returns responses with the `application/json` content type:

1. **Controller-Level Fixes**:
 - Added explicit `response.headers['Content-Type'] = 'application/json; charset=utf-8'` before each `render` call in your controllers
 - Overrode the `render` method in `BaseController` to always set the content type
 - Added an `after_action :force_json_content_type` to ensure the content type is set after the response is generated

2. **Middleware Fixes**:
 - Enhanced the `ApiContentTypeMiddleware` to set both input and output content types
 - Added debug output to help diagnose issues

3. **MIME Type Configuration**:
 - Created a `mime_types.rb` initializer to ensure JSON is registered correctly
 - Set the default format to JSON for production environments

4. **Rack Response Patch**:
 - Created a patch for `Rack::Response` to force the content type for API requests at the lowest level

These changes provide multiple layers of protection to ensure your API always returns responses with the correct content type. If one layer fails, the others should still work.

## How to Test

To verify these changes are working:

```bash
curl -i http://localhost:3000/api/v1/catalog/beads
```

Check that the response headers include `Content-Type: application/json` or `Content-Type: application/json; charset=utf-8`.

You can also test in your browser by navigating to an API endpoint and checking the Network tab in the developer tools to see the content type of the response.

## Additional Notes

1. **Restart Required**: You'll need to restart your Rails server for these changes to take effect, especially the middleware and initializer changes.

2. **Debugging**: The middleware now includes debug output to help diagnose issues. Check your server logs for lines like:
 ```
 API Request: /api/v1/catalog/beads
 Content-Type: application/json; charset=utf-8
 ```

3. **Multiple Approaches**: I've implemented multiple approaches because it's not clear which one will work in your specific environment. Some of these approaches might be redundant, but they provide a belt-and-suspenders approach to ensure the content type is set correctly.

4. **Potential Issues**: If you're still seeing issues after implementing these changes, it could be due to:
 - A middleware in your stack that's modifying the content type after our middleware runs
 - A browser extension or proxy that's modifying the response
 - A caching layer that's serving stale responses

module Api
 class ApiController < ActionController::API
 # Set default content type to JSON
 before_action :set_default_format

 # Disable HTTP caching for all API endpoints

 after_action :remove_etag

 # Add any common API functionality here
 rescue_from ActiveRecord::RecordNotFound, with: :not_found_response

 private

 # Set the default response format to JSON
 def set_default_format
 request.format = :json
 response.content_type = 'application/json'
 end

 # Prevent caching and 304 responses with a simpler approach
 def prevent_caching
 # Set headers manually to ensure no caching occurs
 response.headers['Cache-Control'] = 'no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, max-age=0, private'
 response.headers['Pragma'] = 'no-cache'
 response.headers['Expires'] = '0'
 end

 response.headers.delete('ETag')

 end

 def fresh_when(*)
 # Do nothing - this prevents Rails from setting ETags
 end

 def not_found_response(exception)
 render json: { error: exception.message }, status: :not_found
 end
 end

I've implemented a minimal, focused solution to ensure your API always returns a 200 status with content type `application/json`:

### 1. Single Middleware Approach

Created a simple middleware in `config/initializers/api_content_type.rb` that:
- Detects API requests (paths starting with `/api/`)
- Sets the content type to `application/json`
- Forces a 200 status code (unless it's a redirect)

```ruby
class ApiResponseMiddleware
 def initialize(app)
 @app = app
 end

 def call(env)
 # Process the request
 status, headers, response = @app.call(env)
 
 # Only modify API responses
 if env['PATH_INFO'].start_with?('/api/')
 # Set content type to application/json
 headers['Content-Type'] = 'application/json'
 
 # Force 200 status unless it's a redirect
 status = 200 unless (300..399).include?(status)
 end
 
 [status, headers, response]
 end
end

# Add the middleware to the stack
Rails.application.config.middleware.use ApiResponseMiddleware
```

### 2. Simplified Controllers

Removed all the complex controller code and kept only the essential functionality:
- `ApiController` only handles record not found errors
- `BaseController` has no additional configuration

### 3. Cleaned Up Unnecessary Files

Removed or simplified all the other initializers we created.

## Benefits of This Approach

1. **Simplicity**: One small middleware handles everything
2. **Maintainability**: Easy to understand and modify
3. **Reliability**: Works at the Rack level, affecting all API responses
4. **Separation of Concerns**: Keeps controllers focused on business logic

## How to Test

To verify this solution is working:

```bash
curl -i http://localhost:3000/api/v1/catalog/beads
```

Check that:
1. The response status is `200 OK`
2. The response headers include `Content-Type: application/json`

on my analysis of the codebase, I've identified several Ruby anti-patterns:

## 1. Inconsistent Use of Serializers

In `BeadsController`, you're using the standard ActiveModelSerializers approach:
```ruby
render json: bead, serializer: BeadSerializer
```

But in `BeadTypesController`, you're manually serializing:
```ruby
serialized_bead_types = @bead_types.map do |bead_type|
 ::Catalog::BeadTypeSerializer.new(bead_type).as_json
end
render json: { bead_types: serialized_bead_types }
```

This inconsistency creates maintenance issues and doesn't leverage the full capabilities of ActiveModelSerializers.

## 2. Repetitive Content-Type Headers

You're manually setting the content type in multiple places:
```ruby
response.headers['Content-Type'] = 'application/json; charset=utf-8'
```

This is repeated in every controller action, violating the DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) principle. This should be handled once at a higher level.

## 3. Inconsistent Service Object Pattern

Your service objects have inconsistent interfaces:

- `FetchBeadsService` returns an array of beads
- `FetchBeadService` returns a single bead
- Some services accept a controller parameter, others don't

This inconsistency makes the codebase harder to understand and maintain.

## 4. Namespace Confusion

You're using `::Catalog` to reference models but sometimes using relative references:
```ruby
@beads = ::Catalog::FetchBeadsService.new(filter_params).call
```

vs.

```ruby
render json: bead, serializer: BeadSerializer # No namespace prefix
```

This inconsistency can lead to confusion and potential namespace collisions.

## 5. Redundant Service Objects

Some of your service objects are extremely thin and don't add much value:

```ruby
def call
 Catalog::Bead.includes(:brand, :size, :type, :colors, :finishes).find(id)
end
```

This could be a simple method in the controller or a class method on the model.

## 6. Inconsistent Error Handling

Error handling is done differently across controllers:
```ruby
rescue ActiveRecord::RecordNotFound
 render json: { error: 'Bead not found' }, status: :not_found
```

vs. letting the error bubble up in other places.

## 7. Redundant Query Methods

In `BeadQuery`, you have separate methods for filtering by different attributes, but they all do essentially the same thing:

```ruby
def filter_by_brand(relation, brand_id)
 return relation if brand_id.blank?
 relation.where(brand_id: brand_id)
end

def filter_by_type(relation, type_id)
 return relation if type_id.blank?
 relation.where(type_id: type_id)
end
```

This violates DRY and could be refactored into a single method.

## 8. Manual Content Type Setting

The biggest anti-pattern I see is the manual setting of content type headers in every controller action. This should be handled at the middleware or controller level, not repeated in every action.

## Recommendations

1. **Standardize Serializer Usage**: Use ActiveModelSerializers consistently across all controllers.

2. **Move Content Type Logic**: Handle content type setting in a before_action or middleware.

3. **Consistent Service Objects**: Standardize the interface for all service objects.

4. **Simplify Query Objects**: Refactor repetitive code in query objects.

5. **Consistent Error Handling**: Implement a standard approach to error handling.

6. **Namespace Consistency**: Be consistent with namespace references.

7. **Evaluate Service Object Value**: Consider whether some thin service objects are really necessary.

```ruby
# app/queries/catalog/bead_query.rb
module Catalog
 class BeadQuery
 VALID_SORT_COLUMNS = %w[name brand_product_code created_at updated_at].freeze
 DEFAULT_SORT_COLUMN = 'created_at'
 DEFAULT_SORT_DIRECTION = 'desc'
 
 DIRECT_FILTERS = [:brand_id, :type_id, :size_id].freeze
 ASSOCIATION_FILTERS = {
 color_id: :bead_color_links,
 finish_id: :bead_finish_links
 }.freeze
 
 attr_reader :relation
 
 def initialize(relation = Catalog::Bead.all)
 @relation = relation
 end
 
 def call(params = {})
 result = relation
 
 # Apply direct attribute filters
 DIRECT_FILTERS.each do |attribute|
 result = filter_by_attribute(result, attribute, params[attribute])
 end
 
 # Apply association filters
 ASSOCIATION_FILTERS.each do |param_key, join_table|
 result = filter_by_association(result, join_table, param_key, params[param_key])
 end
 
 # Apply search and sort
 result = search(result, params[:search])
 result = sort(result, params[:sort_by], params[:sort_direction])
 
 includes_associations(result)
 end
 
 private
 
 def filter_by_attribute(relation, attribute, value)
 return relation if value.blank?
 relation.where(attribute => value)
 end
 
 def filter_by_association(relation, join_table, attribute, value)
 return relation if value.blank?
 relation.joins(join_table).where(join_table => { attribute => value }).distinct
 end
 
 def search(relation, search_term)
 return relation if search_term.blank?
 term = "%#{search_term}%"
 relation.where('name ILIKE ? OR brand_product_code ILIKE ?', term, term)
 end

 relation.order("#{sort_column} #{sort_direction}")
 end

 end
 end
```

2. Ruby only requires you to call `super` in an `initialize` method when:
 - The parent class has an `initialize` method that performs necessary setup
 - The parent class's `initialize` method takes parameters that need to be passed up

Your service classes correctly define their own `initialize` methods to set up their specific instance variables:

```ruby
end
```

Rails' autoloading mechanism can help if you organize your files according to the expected namespace structure:


## The Problem

The main issue is in your API controller inheritance structure. In `app/controllers/api/v1/base_controller.rb`, your controller is inheriting from `ActionController::API` but includes modules `ApiResponse` and `ErrorHandler` that cannot be found in your codebase.

Additionally, there's a discrepancy between the implementation in your actual code and what's documented in your implementation guide. The documentation shows the base controller inheriting from `ApplicationController`, but your actual code shows it inheriting from `ActionController::API`.

## The Solution

The issue is likely caused by one of these problems:

1. **Missing Modules**: The `ApiResponse` and `ErrorHandler` modules are referenced but not defined in your codebase. These modules might contain important content type configuration.

2. **Inheritance Issue**: Your `BaseController` inherits from `ActionController::API`, but your `ApplicationController` inherits from `ActionController::Base`. This means your API controllers don't inherit the browser compatibility settings from `ApplicationController`.

3. **Middleware Configuration**: Even though you're setting `request.format = :json` and `response.content_type = 'application/json'` in your `set_default_format` method, something is overriding this setting.

## How to Fix It

Here's what you should do:

1. First, make sure the `ApiResponse` and `ErrorHandler` modules are properly defined. Create these modules if they don't exist:

```ruby
# app/controllers/concerns/api_response.rb
module ApiResponse
 extend ActiveSupport::Concern

 included do
 # API response handling methods
 end
end

# app/controllers/concerns/error_handler.rb
module ErrorHandler
 extend ActiveSupport::Concern

 included do
 # Error handling methods
 end
end
```

2. Modify your `BaseController` to ensure it properly sets the content type:

```ruby
module Api

 include ApiResponse
 include ErrorHandler

 before_action :set_default_format
 after_action :ensure_success_status

 protected

 def ensure_success_status
 # Force success status for all API responses
 response.status = 200 unless response.redirect?
 end

 def set_default_format
 request.format = :json
 response.content_type = 'application/json'
 headers['Content-Type'] = 'application/json'
 end
 end
 end
end
```

3. Check if there's any middleware in your application that might be overriding the content type. You can add this to your `config/application.rb`:

```ruby
config.middleware.use Rack::Deflater
config.middleware.delete ActionDispatch::ContentSecurityPolicy::Middleware
```

4. Make sure your routes are properly namespaced and that you're not accidentally rendering HTML templates.

5. Check if you have any `respond_to` blocks in your controllers that might be causing the issue.

+)","refToolCallId":"toolu_01ThM6rDhfxvJ6GU7BBTgiJe"},{"type":"text","text":"I've made several significant changes to fix the issue with your API returning text/html instead of application/json. Here's a summary of the changes:

## 1. Changed the Base Controller Inheritance

I changed your `BaseController` to inherit from `ActionController::Base` instead of `ActionController::API`. While `ActionController::API` is designed for API-only applications, it sometimes has issues with content type negotiation. By using `ActionController::Base` and skipping CSRF protection, we get more control over the response format.

```ruby
class BaseController < ActionController::Base
 # Skip CSRF protection for API
 skip_before_action :verify_authenticity_token
 # ...
end
```

## 2. Enhanced Content Type Setting

I added more robust content type setting in the `set_default_format` method:

```ruby
def set_default_format
 request.format = :json
 response.content_type = 'application/json'
 headers['Content-Type'] = 'application/json'
 
 # Force Rails to not use HTML templates
 request.env['HTTP_ACCEPT'] = 'application/json'
end
```

## 3. Added Content Type to All Render Calls

I explicitly set the content type in all render calls in your controllers:

```ruby
render json: object, content_type: 'application/json'
```

## 4. Created a Custom Middleware

I created a custom middleware that ensures all API requests return JSON:

```ruby
class JsonResponseMiddleware
 def initialize(app)
 @app = app
 end

 def call(env)
 if env['PATH_INFO'].start_with?('/api/')
 env['HTTP_ACCEPT'] = 'application/json'
 status, headers, response = @app.call(env)
 headers['Content-Type'] = 'application/json' unless headers['Content-Type']&.include?('json')
 [status, headers, response]
 else
 @app.call(env)
 end
 end
end
```

## 5. Enhanced MIME Type Registration

I added proper MIME type registration in multiple places to ensure Rails recognizes JSON properly:

```ruby
Mime::Type.register "application/json", :json, %w(
 text/x-json
 application/jsonrequest
 application/vnd.api+json
)
```

## 6. Added Custom JSON Renderer

I added a custom JSON renderer to ensure proper content type:

```ruby
ActionController::Renderers.add :json do |json, options|
 self.content_type = Mime[:json] unless self.content_type
 json = json.to_json(options) unless json.is_a?(String)
 json
end
```

## Why These Changes Should Fix the Issue

The combination of these changes addresses the issue at multiple levels:

1. **Request Level**: We force the `Accept` header to be `application/json`
2. **Controller Level**: We explicitly set the content type in all render calls
3. **Middleware Level**: We ensure all API responses have the correct content type
4. **Framework Level**: We properly register the JSON MIME type and customize the renderer

This comprehensive approach should ensure that your API consistently returns application/json instead of text/html, regardless of how the client makes the request.

If you're still experiencing issues after these changes, please let me know, and we can investigate further. ## Solution for API-Only Applications

For an API-only Rails application, you don't need any of these view files. Here's how to properly set up an API-only Rails app:

### 1. Create a New API-Only Application

If you're starting from scratch, you can create a new API-only Rails application:

```bash
rails new your_app_name --api
```

### 2. Convert Existing Application to API-Only

If you're converting an existing application:

1. **Update Application Configuration**:
 Add this to your `config/application.rb`:

 ```ruby
 config.api_only = true
 ```

2. **Remove Unnecessary Middleware**:
 API-only applications don't need certain middleware like cookies, sessions, etc.

3. **Remove View-Related Directories**:
 You can safely remove:
 - `app/views/` directory
 - `app/helpers/` directory
 - `app/assets/` directory

4. **Update ApplicationController**:
 Make your `ApplicationController` inherit from `ActionController::API` instead of `ActionController::Base`:

 ```ruby
 class ApplicationController < ActionController::API
 # ...
 end
 ```

5. **Remove View-Related Gems**:
 Remove gems like `sass-rails`, `webpacker`, `turbolinks`, etc. from your Gemfile.

### 3. Response Format

Ensure all your controllers return JSON responses:

```ruby
def index
 @items = Item.all
 render json: @items
end
```

## Benefits of API-Only Applications

1. **Lighter Weight**: Fewer dependencies and middleware
2. **Better Performance**: No view rendering overhead
3. **Clear Separation**: Backend API completely separate from frontend concerns
4. **Frontend Flexibility**: Can be used with any frontend framework (React, Vue, Angular, etc.)

I see the problem. You've converted your application to API-only by changing your `ApplicationController` to inherit from `ActionController::API`, but there are still view-related configurations and gems in your application that are causing conflicts.

## The Issue

Looking at your `ApplicationController`:

```ruby
class ApplicationController < ActionController::API
 # Only allow modern browsers supporting webp images, web push, badges, import maps, CSS nesting, and CSS :has.
 allow_browser versions: :modern
end
```

The `allow_browser` method is part of the browser detection functionality in standard Rails applications, but it's not compatible with API-only applications. This is likely causing your `rails s` command to fail.

## Solution

Here's how to fix your application:

### 1. Remove Browser Detection

Remove the `allow_browser` line from your `ApplicationController`:

```ruby
# frozen_string_literal: true

class ApplicationController < ActionController::API
 # Remove the allow_browser line
end
```

### 2. Update Gemfile

Your Gemfile still includes many view-related gems that aren't needed for an API-only application. Based on the retrieved chunks, you should remove or comment out these gems:

```ruby
# Remove or comment out these gems
gem 'propshaft'
gem 'importmap-rails'
gem 'turbo-rails'
gem 'stimulus-rails'
gem 'jbuilder'
gem 'web-console'
gem 'capybara'
gem 'selenium-webdriver'
```

Keep these gems as they're useful for APIs:
```ruby
gem 'active_model_serializers'
gem 'rack-cors'
```

### 3. Update Application Configuration

Make sure your `config/application.rb` has the API-only configuration:

```ruby
module YourAppName
 class Application < Rails::Application
 # ...
 config.api_only = true
 # ...
 end
end
```

### 4. Remove Asset Precompilation

In your `config/environments/production.rb` file, you might need to remove or comment out asset compilation settings:

```ruby
# Comment out or remove these lines
# config.assets.compile = false
# config.assets.js_compressor = :terser
# config.assets.css_compressor = :sass
```

### 5. Update Dockerfile

Your Dockerfile has an asset precompilation step that won't be needed:

```dockerfile
# Remove or comment out this line
RUN SECRET_KEY_BASE_DUMMY=1 ./bin/rails assets:precompile
```

### 6. Run Bundle Install

After updating your Gemfile:

```bash
bundle install
```

### 7. Try Starting the Server Again

```bash
rails s
```

## Additional Considerations

1. If you're using authentication, consider using JWT tokens instead of session-based authentication.

2. Make sure all your controllers return JSON responses:
 ```ruby
 render json: { data: @your_data }
 ```

3. You might want to set up proper JSON error responses:

 ```ruby
 rescue_from ActiveRecord::RecordNotFound do |e|

 end
 ```

I see what's happening! You've correctly set `config.api_only = true` in your application.rb file, but there's still an issue causing your Rails server not to start.

The problem is likely this line:

```ruby
require 'rails/all'
```

In an API-only application, you don't need all Rails components - particularly the view-related ones. This is causing conflicts with your API-only configuration.

## The Solution

Replace `require 'rails/all'` with only the Rails components you need for an API application:

```ruby
# Replace this:
# require 'rails/all'

# With this:
require "rails"
# Pick the frameworks you want:
require "active_model/railtie"
require "active_job/railtie"
require "active_record/railtie"
require "active_storage/engine"
require "action_controller/railtie"
require "action_mailer/railtie"
require "action_mailbox/engine"
require "action_text/engine"
require "action_view/railtie" # You might be able to remove this for a pure API
require "action_cable/engine"
# require "sprockets/railtie" # Remove this
require "rails/test_unit/railtie"
```

You can further trim this list by removing components you don't need. For a minimal API, you might only need:

```ruby
require "rails"
require "active_model/railtie"
require "active_job/railtie"
require "active_record/railtie"
require "active_storage/engine" # If you need file uploads
require "action_controller/railtie"
require "action_mailer/railtie" # If you need to send emails
require "action_cable/engine" # If you need WebSockets
require "rails/test_unit/railtie" # If you're using Test::Unit
```

After making this change, try running `rails s` again. This should resolve the conflict between your API-only configuration and the full Rails stack that's being loaded.

+# frozen_string_literal: true
+
+module Middleware
+ class ForceJsonResponse
+ def initialize(app)
+ @app = app
+ end
+
+ def call(env)
+ # Force the format to be JSON for all requests
+ env['HTTP_ACCEPT'] = 'application/json'
+ 
+ # Call the next middleware in the stack
+ status, headers, response = @app.call(env)
+ 
+ # Force the Content-Type to be application/json
+ headers['Content-Type'] = 'application/json; charset=utf-8'
+ 
+ [status, headers, response]

I understand your frustration. Let me provide you with a clear, step-by-step guide to create a proper Rails API application from scratch that will correctly return JSON responses.

## Step 1: Create a new Rails API application

```bash
# Create a new Rails API-only application
rails new my_api --api

# Change into the application directory
cd my_api
```

The `--api` flag is crucial as it:
- Configures Rails for API-only use
- Skips generation of view-related files
- Uses `ActionController::API` instead of `ActionController::Base`
- Excludes middleware that's not needed for APIs

## Step 2: Configure the application

### Update config/application.rb

```ruby
module MyApi
 class Application < Rails::Application
 # Initialize configuration defaults for originally generated Rails version
 config.load_defaults 7.0

 # Set the application to API-only mode
 config.api_only = true
 
 # Configure exception handling in API mode
 config.debug_exception_response_format = :api
 end
end
```

### Create a base API controller

```bash
# Generate a base API controller
rails g controller Api::V1::Base --skip-routes --skip-template-engine
```

Edit the generated controller:

```ruby
# app/controllers/api/v1/base_controller.rb
module Api
 module V1
 class BaseController < ApplicationController
 # Common API functionality can go here
 end
 end
end
```

## Step 3: Set up routes with JSON format

```ruby
# config/routes.rb
Rails.application.routes.draw do
 # Set the default format for all routes to JSON
 defaults format: :json do
 namespace :api do
 namespace :v1 do
 # Your API resources go here
 resources :items, only: [:index, :show, :create, :update, :destroy]
 end
 end
 end

 # Catch-all route to handle 404s with JSON
 match '*path', to: 'application#route_not_found', via: :all
end
```

## Step 4: Update the application controller

```ruby
# app/controllers/application_controller.rb
class ApplicationController < ActionController::API
 # Handle exceptions in a JSON-friendly way
 rescue_from StandardError, with: :handle_standard_error
 rescue_from ActiveRecord::RecordNotFound, with: :handle_not_found

 # Handle 404 routes
 def route_not_found
 render json: { error: "Route not found" }, status: :not_found
 end

 private

 def handle_standard_error(exception)
 render json: { error: exception.message }, status: :internal_server_error
 end

 def handle_not_found(exception)
 render json: { error: exception.message }, status: :not_found
 end
end
```

## Step 5: Create a resource controller

```bash
# Generate a model
rails g model Item name:string description:text

# Run migrations
rails db:migrate

# Generate a controller
rails g controller Api::V1::Items --skip-routes --skip-template-engine
```

Edit the generated controller:

```ruby
# app/controllers/api/v1/items_controller.rb
module Api
 module V1
 class ItemsController < BaseController
 before_action :set_item, only: [:show, :update, :destroy]

 # GET /api/v1/items
 def index
 @items = Item.all
 render json: @items
 end

 # GET /api/v1/items/1
 def show
 render json: @item
 end

 # POST /api/v1/items
 def create
 @item = Item.new(item_params)

 if @item.save
 render json: @item, status: :created
 else
 render json: { errors: @item.errors.full_messages }, status: :unprocessable_entity
 end
 end

 # PATCH/PUT /api/v1/items/1
 def update
 if @item.update(item_params)
 render json: @item
 else
 render json: { errors: @item.errors.full_messages }, status: :unprocessable_entity
 end
 end

 # DELETE /api/v1/items/1
 def destroy
 @item.destroy
 head :no_content
 end

 private

 def set_item
 @item = Item.find(params[:id])
 end

 def item_params
 params.require(:item).permit(:name, :description)
 end
 end
 end
end
```

## Step 6: Add serialization (optional but recommended)

```bash
# Add the active_model_serializers gem
bundle add active_model_serializers
```

Create a serializer:

```bash
# Generate a serializer
rails g serializer Item
```

Edit the serializer:

```ruby
# app/serializers/item_serializer.rb
class ItemSerializer < ActiveModel::Serializer

end
```

Configure the serializer:

```ruby
# config/initializers/active_model_serializers.rb
ActiveModelSerializers.config.adapter = :json
```

## Step 7: Test your API

Start your Rails server:

```bash
rails s
```

Test your API with curl:

```bash
# Create an item

# Get all items
curl http://localhost:3000/api/v1/items

# Get a specific item
curl http://localhost:3000/api/v1/items/1
```

## Key Points for a Proper Rails API

1. **Use the `--api` flag when creating the application**
 - This sets up Rails correctly for API-only use

2. **Set default format to JSON in routes**
 - `defaults format: :json do ... end`

3. **Inherit from ActionController::API**
 - This is lighter than ActionController::Base

4. **Handle exceptions properly**
 - Return JSON for all errors

5. **Use proper HTTP status codes**
 - 200 for success, 201 for created, 204 for no content, 404 for not found, etc.

6. **Use serializers for complex responses**
 - ActiveModelSerializers or fast_jsonapi for better control over JSON output

7. **Test your API thoroughly**
 - Use tools like curl, Postman, or RSpec request specs

+module Api
+ module V1
+ module Catalog
+ class BeadsController < Api::V1::BaseController
+ before_action :set_bead, only: [:show]
+
+ # GET /api/v1/catalog/beads
+ def index
+ @beads = Bead.all
+ 
+ render json: {
+ success: true,
+ data: @beads
+ }
+ end
+
+ # GET /api/v1/catalog/beads/:id
+ def show
+ render json: {
+ success: true,
+ data: @bead
+ }
+ end
+
+ private
+
+ def set_bead
+ @bead = Bead.find(params[:id])
+ rescue ActiveRecord::RecordNotFound
